notes: Vardaman Hall took its name from the race-baiting, populist politician, James K. Vardaman, who served terms as the governor and senator of Mississippi in the early twentieth century. Vardaman openly advocated lynching as a way to maintain white supremacy, so hanging the effigies from a building that was named in his honor was sadly fitting.

I first became aware of the burning of effigies on the grounds of the campus, ironically enough, when I was reading “Letters of Support” in the James Howard Meredith Collection at the University of Mississippi’s Archives and Special Collections. I came across a letter from a fifteen-year-old white girl from Audobon, New Jersey named Eileen Potts, who wrote that, by hearing about the burned effigy, “for the first time I could really imagine what was going on there [in Oxford, Mississippi].” I got up from my desk in the reading room to ask the archivists if they had any images of the effigy referenced in the letter, which they did not, or if they had heard about the effigy, which they had not, but a few hours later I came across a newspaper clipping of the image in one of the folders labeled “Negative Letters,” a massive understatement, to be sure.

Initially I had intended to embed an image after the first paragraph of this text, but due to copyright restrictions I have linked to the original image instead. I think it is important to show these images because they so powerfully illustrate the level of violence people like James Meredith confronted in 1962, so I want to make it clear that in no way am I trying to paper over this violent history by omitting an image from this piece.

The enclosure with this letter was an article from the 11 September 1944 issue of Life titled “P.A.C.: CIO’s Political Action Committee Raises a Storm” that included the photo and description of the effigy hanged in Miami in 1939.

In the intervening years, white southerners had used effigies to intimidate bus boycotters in Montgomery, Alabama, high school students integrating Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas, protesters driving through Virginia on their way to the March on Washington, and others. In Panel 15 from Jacob Lawrence’s The Migration of the Negro (1940–1941), the absence of a body marks the barren, washed-out landscape as a place burdened with the memory of lynching. The mourning figure sitting in the foreground reminds us that the noose left hanging from the branch is evidence enough that the burden of history—a history sagging under the weight of many thousands gone—encroaches upon the present.
